Award.AwardTitle: SHB: Type I (EXP): Collaborative Research: A Portable Power-Assist Orthosis to Aid Elderly Persons in Locomotion

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops a portable power-assist orthosis to address the problems of impaired mobility due to lower-extremity weakness. This robotic orthosis actively assists the user's joint motion according to his or her motion intent, and thus enables the user to perform certain critical, power-consuming tasks (such as the sit-to-stand motion) independently. The orthosis is powered with a high-performance actuation approach, namely chemo-fluidic actuation, which combines the high-power-density pneumatic actuators with a high-energy-density monopropellant-based pneumatic supply. In addition to the new actuation approach, the orthosis also features a new structure and user interface for effective load transfer and easy donning-doffing; and an effective motion control algorithm to enable interactive power assist according to the user's motion intent. With the portable power-assist orthosis, the users reduce the reliance on the assistance by caregivers, enjoy a significantly improved life quality, and stay physically active to avoid the aforementioned issues associated with the sedentary life style.

This project has broader impact to assistive technologies and can improve mobility of elderly individuals and people suffering from the impaired mobility due to lower-extremity weakness. The project can potentially reduce a considerable amount of physical assistance taking care of these individuals, and the cost of time and manpower in the care. The research of the project is incorporated into education activities by utilizing the rehabilitation robotics as an innovative education medium.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The rapid aging of the U.S. population nowadays is unprecedented in history: the number of older adults will double in the next 25 years.  By 2030, there will 72 million older adults, accounting for 20% of the general population.  As a significant consequence of such trend, a large number of older adults suffer from mobility impairment, resulting from the gradual degeneration of the musculoskeletal structure, or the related musculoskeletal or neural pathologies (e.g. stroke).  Such individuals are more likely to live in a sedentary lifestyle, and suffer from the various problems associated with the sedentary lifestyle, e.g. high blood pressure, depression, obesity, etc.

The research in this project aims at addressing the mobility problem with portable power-assist orthoses, which are wearable assistive devices that directly apply physical assistance to the users’ limbs and joints (knee and ankle in this case).  To make them suitable for prolonged wearing, these orthoses need to be very compact and lightweight, which is the main challenge we tried to overcome in our research.  We first attempted to use pneumatic actuators to power the orthoses, because they generate high force output at very light weight.  However, the difficulty of incorporating a mobile pneumatic supply diminishes the practicality of pneumatically actuated orthoses.  Subsequently, we tried to use the traditional motor power, which is more convenient to use for such portable devices.  To make the devices practical, we intentionally chose smaller actuators to reduce the weight, but such choice also affects the assistive torques the orthoses can provide.  Additionally, for the knee joint, the most important situation that needs assistance is the standing-up process, and in the subsequent walking process the knee does not need much assistance at all (the major source of power for walking is the ankle).  As such, our final technical decision is to create a system of two separate devices, including: 1) a semi-wearable sit-to-stand assistive device that pushes the thigh of the user to help him/her to stand up, and it can easily detached once the user reaches the standing posture; and 2) a wearable ankle orthosis that assists the ankle motion during walking.  This system is expected to balance the function (motion assistance) and the load (extra weight the user needs to carry), and have a good potential for future daily use.  Over the course of the project, we completed four major iterations of the orthosis design, and the latest devices have shown good performance in the human testing.

In addition to the hardware design of the orthoses, we have also conducted research in developing new algorithms to detect the user’s intention of motion, such that the devices can provide the desired assistance according to the user’s intention.  We collected motion data from 10 participants, and with these data we used machine learning methods to develop the intent recognizers.  The first generation of the intent recognizer is based on the Support Vector Machine (SVM) method, which provides good performance but also requires heavy computation load.  The second-generation intent recognizer is based on extreme learning machine (ELM) and multilayer perceptron (MLP) methods, both of which are able to provide satisfactory performance at reduced computation load.  In the future we will integrate the intent recognizer into the power-assist orthoses to obtain truly smart assistive devices to improve the mobility and quality of life for the older adult users.
